questions.question: Please take your shoes .......................... before entering the temple.
questions.description: To take a piece of clothing off is to remove it.

questions.question: Raj has taken ......................... scuba diving.
questions.description: To take up something is to start a new hobby or activity.

questions.question: Selena takes ............................. her grandmother.
questions.description: To take after somebody is to resemble them.

questions.question: The minister was forced to take his offensive remarks .........................
questions.description: To take something back is to withdraw a statement.

questions.question: This blouse is too loose for you. You must take it .........................
questions.description: To take a garment in is to make it tighter.

questions.question: As our business expands, we will take more people .............................
questions.description: To take somebody on is to employ them.

questions.question: I don’t think I can take ........................... this responsibility.
questions.description: To take on a task is to undertake it.

questions.question: You might have had a bad day at work but you can’t take it .............................. on me.
questions.description: To take it out on somebody is to relieve your frustration by treating them badly.

questions.question: After his father died, he took ............................ their family business.
questions.description: To take over something is to assume responsibility for it.

questions.question: The girl took ........................... her foster parents almost instantly.
questions.description: To take to somebody is to like them.

questions.question: As soon as we saw the leopard, we took ......................... our heels.
questions.description: To take to one’s heels is to run to escape danger.

questions.question: He took ............................ farming after retirement.
questions.description: To take up something is to undertake it.
